p.s: Description of Amycolatopsis albidoflavus sp. nov.
Amycolatopsis albidoflavus (al.bi.do.fla'vus. L. adj. albidus white; L. adj. flavus yellow; M.L. adj. albidoflavus whitish yellow)
Forms well-developed aerial mycelium and vegetative mycelium.
Both of them fragment into rod-shaped elements.
The aerial mycelium is white and the vegetative mycelium is yellow.
A yellow soluble pigment is produced on rich media.
Aerobic, Gram-positive, non-acid-fast.
Catalase-positive.
H2S is produced.
Nitrate is reduced to nitrite.
Growth occurs between 10 and 37 °C.
Growth does not occur at 45 °C.
Acid is produced from adonitol, L-arabinose, D-cellobiose, D-galactose, meso-erythritol, D-fructose, glycerol, meso-inositol, D-lactose, D-mannose, sucrose, D-trehalose and D-xylose.
No acid is produced from dglucose, maltose, D-mannitol, D-melezitose, melibiose, methyl α-D-glucoside, D-raffinose, L-rhamnose, salicin, L-sorbose, D-sorbitol and D-xylitol.
Casein, aesculin, gelatin, hypoxanthine, starch, DL-tyrosine and xanthine are decomposed.
Exhibits weak urease activity.
Growth occurs on 7% NaCl.
Type IV cell wall (meso-diaminopimelic acid, arabinose and galactose in the cell wall).
Muramic acid is in an N-acetyl form.
The major menaquinone is MK-9(H4).
The phospholipid profiles contain phosphatidylmethylethanolamine and phosphatidylinositol (a phospholipid type PII pattern).
Mycolic acids are not present.
The predominant fatty acid is iso-branched hexadecanoic acid.
Saturated, unsaturated and branched-chain fatty acids are also present.
The G­C content of the DNA is 68±5 mol%.
Isolated from soil.
Originally deposited in the ATCC by Bristol-Myers Co.
The type strain is IMSNU 22139T (=KCTC 9471T=ATCC 53205T).
